title: 111_hr4796
content: The Act may be cited as the "Medicare Secondary Payer Enhancement Act of 2010". Calculation and direct payment of MSP claims. The Medicare Secondary Payer Enhancement Act of 2010 allows for the calculation and direct reimbursement of conditional payments for settlement purposes involving a claimant and an applicable plan. The Medicare Secondary Payer Enhancement Act of 2010 allows claimants and plans to calculate and reimburse conditional payments to the Trust Fund based on available billing data for items and services provided. The Medicare Secondary Payer Enhancement Act of 2010 allows reimbursement for items and services provided to a claimant. The Secretary has the ability to contest the amount of payment within a 75-day period after reimbursement to the Trust Fund. The Secretary can contest reimbursement amounts owed under the Medicare Secondary Payer Enhancement Act of 2010. A final demand for the remaining balance may be issued to the claimant or plan, who can either reimburse the Trust Fund or appeal the Secretary's determination. In any appeal, the burden of proof lies with the claimant or plan. The claimant or applicable plan must demonstrate the correctness of reimbursement made to the Trust fund. A request for final demand for reimbursement can be made in case of a settlement, judgment, or payment involving items and services provided to the claimant. The burden of proof lies with the claimant or plan in any appeal. The claimant or applicable plan must request a final demand for reimbursement within 60 days of a settlement, judgment, or payment. The Secretary will respond within 60 days with the final demand, and the claimant or plan can then reimburse the Trust Fund accordingly. The Secretary must provide a final demand for reimbursement within 60 days of a settlement, judgment, or payment. Failure to do so releases the claimant, plan, or recipient from reimbursement obligations. The Secretary will establish a right of appeal and appeals process for any payment made under this title for an item or service under a primary plan. Applicable plans or entities receiving payment are not liable for reimbursement related to the request for final demand. The Secretary will establish an appeals process for payments made under this title, including review by an administrative law judge and review board, with access to judicial review in the district court where the appellant is located. The process will be similar to appeals procedures used for subsection (a). The appeals process for payments under this title will include a 90-day timeframe for certain applicable plans and reimbursements. SEC. 3. THRESHOLD. In an amendment to the Social Security Act, Section 1862(b)(2)(B)(ii) is revised to require repayment for certain payments under the title, with exceptions for specific types of payments. The amendment to the Social Security Act now requires repayment for payments not exceeding $5,000 to claimants by applicable plans. The amendment to the Social Security Act now requires repayment for payments not exceeding $5,000 to claimants by applicable plans. In cases involving ongoing responsibility for medical payments, the payment should only include the cumulative value of medical payments made and the purchase price of any annuity or similar instrument, adjusted annually based on the Consumer Price Index. The amendment to the Social Security Act requires repayment for payments not exceeding $5,000 to claimants by applicable plans, based on the Consumer Price Index. The amendments apply to payments made 3 months after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. REPORTING REQUIREMENT SAFE HARBORS. Section 1862(b)(8) of the Social Security Act is amended to allow for civil money penalties of up to $1,000 per day for noncompliance. The severity of the penalty will depend on the intentional nature of the violation. Additionally, safe harbors from sanctions can be proposed and accepted within a 60-day period after the enactment of this amendment. The Secretary, in consultation with the Attorney General, will establish safe harbors from penalties or sanctions under subparagraph (E) after considering proposals and public comments. SEC. 5 of the Social Security Act is amended to modify reporting requirements for entities to not access or report beneficiary social security numbers or health identification claim numbers. SEC. 6 addresses the statute of limitations. SEC. 6 amends the statute of limitations for actions brought under the Social Security Act, setting a three-year limit from the date of notice of a settlement or payment. The amendment applies to actions brought six months after the enactment of the Act. Section 1862(b) of the Social Security Act is amended to include a new paragraph regarding user fees. The Secretary will assess and collect fees for direct conditional payment reimbursement, with a fee of $30 for each payment reimbursed. The Secretary will assess and collect fees for direct conditional payment reimbursement. Each request for a recover demand letter of conditional payment incurs a $30 fee. Fees specified will be adjusted for inflation starting from fiscal year 2010. The Secretary adjusts fees based on changes in the Consumer Price Index. Unpaid fees after 30 days are treated as a claim of the US Government.
